Authors:
Yuksel Gezgin, Kristian F Nielsen, Rengin Eltem, Jens C
Frisvad, Jakob B Nielsen
Title:
Chemotaxonomic and molecular fingerprinting of Aspergillus
section Nigri from Turkish dried figs
Keywords:
Black Aspergilli, Dried figs, Mass spectrometry,
Phenotypic fingerprinting, Molecular identification.
Abstract:
Species in Aspergillus section Nigri (AsN) cause
significant problems as contaminants, of dried foods as well as fresh
products such as grapes and onions. Some species are also important
industrial organisms for the production enzymes and organic acids.
Accurate methods for AsN identification and differentiation are of
paramount importance as several of them can produce mycotoxins. Here we
studied AsN species from dried figs using liquid chromatography-mass
spectrometric (LC-MS) and compared the results to morphological and
molecular analysis. Importantly, the classification based on chemical
analysis agreed with the morphological inspection and the sequencing of
the partial beta-tubulin (B-tub) and calmodulin (CaM) encoding genes. In
total 132 isolates were classified, 128 from dried figs and 4 from fig
orchard soil samples. The strains were identified as A. tubingensis
(72), A. welwitschiae (28), A. niger (2), a potential hybrid of
Aspergillus tubingensis-A. niger (1), A. uvarum (1), and interestingly
A. brasiliensis (28) strains. This is first time the latter has been
found a high frequency (21%) in any habitat. This is the first report of
successfully using LC-MS for chemotaxonomic phenotypic fingerprinting of
closely related black Aspergillus species. When the strains were grown
on rich agar media as well as rice and figs, none of the isolates were
found to produce ochratoxin A and only 7 isolates produced fumonisins
(B2, B4 and B6), these came from A. welwitschiae (6 of 28 isolates) and
A. niger (1 of 2 isolates).
